questions.question_text:
A customer will use the vRealize Automation platform for production and development deployments to the same vSphere cluster. One of their vSphere templates will only be licensed for use in development and must not be used for production.
The customer has defined a tag category called `environment` with three possible values `development`, `test` and `production` to differentiate the environments.
Which two design decisions will ensure that the requirements are met? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Define a tag of ג€!environment:productionג€ on the licensed image mapping
choices.A: Define a tag of ג€environment:developmentג€ on the Cloud Zone
choices.D: Define a tag of ג€environment:developmentג€ in all development Cloud Templates
choices.C: Define a tag of ג€environment:developmentג€ on the licensed image mapping
choices.E: Define a tag of ג€environment:productionג€ on the Cloud Zone

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
C , D are corrected

Selected Answer: CD
Since production and development VMs are in the same cluster, the cloud zone cannot be used as a point of separation - so A and E are out.
The question only mentions that the license is for development, not production. So it doesn't make sense to put a production tag on the image mapping. B is out.
In addition, the question doesn't say *which* kind of tag, so it is legit to answer C & D. The image gets the capability tag of 'dev' and the cloud template gets the constraint tag of 'dev'.

Selected Answer: CD
I would set the tag environment:development on the Image Mapping and use it as a constraint in the corresponding cloud template. (C and D)
A and C. The Image Mapping has a constraint tag, not capability tag.

questions.question_text:
A customer has a requirement that an external auditing system must be updated when specific Cloud Templates are released.
Which combination of event topic and subscription filter would meet the customer's requirement? (Choose two.)

choices.D: Deploy a Workspace ONE Access node and protect it with Fault Tolerance.
choices.B: Deploy a Workspace ONE Access node and protect it with vSphere HA.
choices.A: Deploy a Workspace ONE Access cluster and protect it with vSphere HA.
choices.C: Deploy a Workspace ONE Access cluster and protect it with Fault Tolerance.

discussion.content: Should be B as SLA is 95% that's 3h 37m 21s down time per month is ok. In addition, SLA applicable for week days only.

Selected Answer: B
Totally agree with @0win. 3:37h down time per month is more than enough for frequent updates and common outages. B because this is the minimal deployment footprint. 

Not sure, if FT is even supported with WS1. Generally not needed, because you are running it in a Cluster.
But why a Cluster? We need a minimal footprint and the availbility is with 95% small. I take B

comments.content: A cluster is not required. It's best practice, but it's not required. You absolutely can deploy one node for WS1A.

A cluster is always required, what if there is some VM Issue, suck as disk issue and if its one appliance, SLA cannot be maintained, it will be a single point of failure. Ideal to go for a cluster with HA

discussion.content: agree A
Should be A, FT has more footprint by design
